data.title: Winter weather advisory issued in Southern Tier, Hudson Valley. How much snow to expect.
data.meta_description: The snow isn't done yet. A winter weather advisory is in effect Wednesday.
data.text:
Most of the snow has melted but winter isn't over yet.

A winter weather advisory has been issued by the National Weather Service for the Southern Tier and a portion of the Mohawk Valley and Hudson Valley. The advisory runs from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. in Chemung, Tompkins, Cortland, Chenango, Otsego, Tioga, Broome, Delaware and Sullivan counties. The advisory expires at 11 p.m. in western Greene and western Ulster counties.

Total snow accumulations of 2 to 5 inches are expected. The heaviest snow is expected from noon to 6 p.m. The NWS warns that road conditions will be slick and could impact the evening commute.

Elevations greater than 1,200 feet above sea level could receive 3 to 5 inches of snow, while lower elevations will likely collect 1 to 2 inches.

Temperatures are forecast to rise back into the 40s on Thursday.

Think when you ride: We asked experts for snowmobile safety tips in wake of crashes

What is lake effect snow?: Here's how it happens and how much snow it can bring with it

Predicted snowfall in New York
